post.excerpt: Puerto Rico’s electrical recovery and the efforts for a sustainable future
post.content:
In the heart of Puerto Rico’s Central Mountains, excitement is brewing. 

Not the bad, pit-in-your-stomach anticipation that the island has dealt with hurricane season after hurricane season. Instead, there’s hope for a more sustainable future.. 

The clanking of hammers can be heard on the roofs of dozens of homes throughout Adjuntas, a town of fewer than 4,500 people, living in less than a square mile, where life moves a little slower than on the rest of the island.

Next time the island’s power grid goes dark, refrigerators in Adjuntas will stay humming, oxygen machines at El Hogar La Misericordia nursing home will keep flowing and street lights will stay lit. 

Video loading…

Just down the road from the town center, a coral-colored building with a welcoming porch and red, white and blue Puerto Rican flag — the pro-independence verison — is bustling. Inside Casa Pueblo, a community social organization, one of the largest celebrations the region has seen in years is being planned in March 2023.

Over the past five years, Casa Pueblo has helped thousands of its neighbors feel a sense of peace, security and unity through education and advocacy — and now solar power. 

But, for hundreds of other Puerto Ricans, power blackouts are still a common occurrence. After leadership changes, billions of federal government dollars and the privatization of the power utility, there is a plague of frustration when the lights don’t turn on.

For many, hope is teetering on the edge.

Financial woes

Over the last two decades, Puerto Rico has struggled significantly to manage its money. The government spends billions of dollars more than it brings in. Gross domestic product growth has slowed and even declined in recent years. Per capita gross national income in Puerto Rico has remained less than a third of what it is on the U.S. mainland. 

In 2015, Puerto Rico’s Governor Alejandro García Padilla announced the island had amassed an “unpayable” debt of over $70 billion — or about $20,000 for each of the island’s more than 3 million people. 

Congress was forced to aid the territory in ensuing a bankruptcy process that lead to the largest public debt restructuring in U.S. history.

The Puerto Rico Oversight, Management , and Economic Stability Act was signed into law in 2016 and created the Financial Oversight and Management Board that was charged with achieving fiscal responsibility and economic stability.

However, confusion around how much debt Puerto Rico truly holds remains complicated. 

In 2017, the governor disbanded a commission founded by his predecessor to audit the public debt. The next year, the FOMB asked a law firm to conduct an audit — but there have been questions about conflicts of interests in the investigation. Other audit proposals by the legislature have failed.

Nevertheless, the oversight board’s plan to reduce Puerto Rico’s debt by 80% was approved by a federal court in March 2022.

Decades of corruption, mismanagement , and economic contraction had led to this financial implosion — which was only exacerbated by Hurricanes Irma and Maria. In early September 2017, Irma decimated a large part of the island’s infrastructure, despite not making landfall. A third of Puerto Rico was left without clean water. Two-thirds of the island was left without electricity.

Maria hit Puerto Rico as a strong Category 4 storm three weeks later. All that was left of Puerto Rico’s electric grid was destroyed — leaving the whole island without power.

It was the largest outage in American history.

But for many non-Puerto Ricans, all of the remembered mainland U.S. involvement was then-President Donald Trump throwing paper towels to a crowd at a hurricane relief center in the days following the storm. At the time, millions were still without power.

“Casa Pueblo became an energetic oasis.”

Alexis Massol, who co-founded the organization 40 years ago

Those who were on the island remember hardship, frustration and a struggle to survive.

For about a dozen residents back at  El Hogar La Misericordia, the outage meant crucial insulin could not stay cold, food could not be cooked and medical equipment could not be used.

But just across town, the porch lights were still on.

“Casa Pueblo became an energetic oasis,” Alexis Massol, who co-founded the organization 40 years ago, said.

The organization welcomed the region of less than 20,000 inside to store medicines, run dialysis machines and charge flashlights. 

“It was a blessing,” said Dali Rullan, 74, president of the nursing home’s board of directors. 

After Maria, the organization also secured solar lamps and generators and helped provide them to urban and rural residents in Adjuntas, filling a void where the government power system failed.

Building alternatives

In 1980, Massol and his wife had a vision: to help transform their hometown of Adjuntas.

When a Puerto Rican government-backed endeavor sought to mine the region’s rich silver, gold and copper deposits, Casa Pueblo became a successful organizing force against what Massol called a potential “ecological catastrophe.”

The organization has since also created community spaces for art, music and environmental discovery on their multi-building campus, in addition to launching a radio broadcast and newspaper.

But after coming to the community’s aid in 2017, Massol, along with his son Arturo, realized Casa Pueblo had an opportunity to directly change the people of Adjuntas’ lives.

In collaboration with the Honnold Foundation and the Adjuntas Solar Energy Community Association, Casa Pueblo has done just that.

Together, over 350 solar energy projects have been sponsored in the Adjuntas region since Hurricane Maria. Midnight blue solar panels can be spotted along the roofs throughout the hilly community, including 130 residential homes, six grocery stores and a fire station.

All now have greater electricity access with solar power.

[ILLUSTRATED INTERACTIVE]

On March 18, Casa Pueblo — along with its collaborators —hosted one of the largest community events the region has ever seen. Hundreds of people descended on the town for Marcha del Sol, celebrating the area’s energy self-sufficiency with the connection of several buildings to the solar microgrid, including a town church, pharmacy and bakery.

“We are changing our soul and our way of being,” Massol said in his speech to hundreds of brightly-colored parade goers. 

“You have to make comprehensive, loving, respectful men and women,” he said. “In this process we are creating an alternative Puerto Rico, not only with solar panels and forest, but with the being that will manage all that time.”

“We are transforming the world of Adjuntas, because by transforming the world of Adjuntas, together we can transform the global world.”

Alexis Massol

Paso a paso — step by step —  he said, Casa Pueblo wants equality and justice for all.

“We are transforming the world of Adjuntas, because by transforming the world of Adjuntas, together we can transform the global world,” he said.

However, as the parade full of kids with painted faces, noisemakers and Puerto Rican flags passed by buildings, turquoise tarps covering up storm destruction remain a reminder of annual frustration.

A tough transition

The effects of Maria were devastating for the entire island. Thousands of Puerto Ricans died. 

It took almost a year for  power to be fully restored. 

Part of this stems from the fact that Puerto Rico’s Electric Power Authority has more customers than any other public electric utility in the U.S. However, it only provides half as much power to similarly-sized services on a per-customer basis.

In response to the growing financial crisis and a plague of problems with restoring and modernizing the island’s electrical grid, the government turned to LUMA — a private corporation whose ownership is split between a Texas-based infrastructure company, Quanta Services, and ATCO, a Canadian-based utilities group.

REPLACE W photo stry

In 2020, LUMA was awarded a 15-year contract to transform the island’s power. But to many Puerto Ricans, LUMA is an unwelcome outsider. Protests outside of the company’s headquarters and substations — often led by Puerto Rican electrical union UTIER— are a common sight.

Luis Moulier, 49, spent more than 20 years as a lineman for PREPA, working to connect the island’s residents to the power grid. Now he is a truck driver for the government health clinic. 

Edith Soto, 41, worked for 14 years in customer service at PREPA. 

“I loved my job,” she said. “I love interacting with people.”

She’s now a secretary within the Puerto Rico natural resources department.

“I hate it,” she said.

Karlexy Rosario, 50, was a lineman for two decades. He is now a truck driver for the island’s department of education.

Rosario, Soto and Moulier are three of about 4,000 government employees that chose to change their career instead of following Puerto Rico’s attempt at fixing its dual electrical and financial crisis by privatizing the grid.

“They don’t know the work,” Moulier said. “If you don’t know how to turn on the light here, you are going to be lost.”

“They don’t know the work. If you don’t know how to turn on the light here, you are going to be lost.”

Luis Moulier, former lineman.

During the privatization process, Moulier, along with Soto and Rosario, chose to be reassigned to a new government agency instead of joining LUMA. They said they didn’t believe in the private sector. 

UTIER subsequently saw its membership decrease by 80 percent. The reason isn’t because of the union itself, but because of the government’s desire to privatize. 

If members had joined LUMA, they said they would have lost part of their retirement benefits and ability to collectively bargain. 

“Privatization is worrying and dangerous as it destroys unions and workers won’t have any protection,” President of UTIER Josue Mitjá said. “It is modern enslavement. It justifies random layoffs and cuts off every benefit.”

A representative from LUMA did not respond to multiple requests for comment over several weeks by time of publication, but in a transition document, the company told PREPA employees it wanted to be transparent. 

“You are our priority,” the document said. “We need your knowledge, expertise and dedication.”

PREPA employees were offered the same health insurance plan as well as a one-time choice to stay in their previous pension plan, according to the transition document. Moreover, LUMA said it would also continue to contribute if individuals stayed with their PREPA pension plan.

Privatization in practice

LUMA took the helm of Puerto Rico’s power transmission and distribution on June 1, 2021. Days later, a massive explosion occurred at a substation outside of San Juan.

The incident cut the power to 1 in 10 residents on the island, with some people left in the dark for weeks.

Fifteen months later, Hurricane Fiona made landfall on Puerto Rico as a Category 1 storm. 

Almost immediately, most residents were without power after 80%of the island’s grid was damaged. Two weeks later, over 100,000 residents were still without power.

Moulier said the delays were due in part to LUMA’s struggles.

“We lost the power for a month and that’s not acceptable,” he said. “That is not acceptable.”

Prior to LUMA’s takeover, he said a similarly-sized storm would have only taken a week or two for power to be fully restored.

“It’s ridiculous,” he said.

Throughout the island, many power poles have tangled messes of cables — a stark contrast  to the more-organized cables on the U.S. mainland. 

Mitjá added that the continued mismanagement of the power system will continue to create more power outages through Puerto Rico. The citizens, though, will be the ones that have to feel the maintenance costs.

According to the U.S. Energy Information Administration, Puerto Rico consumes nearly 70 times more energy than it produces, and the island has one of the most expensive energy costs in the United States — second only to Hawaii. 

Prices have only gone up since LUMA’s takeover, despite the fact the company has been reliant on billions of Federal Emergency Management Agency dollars to operate. 

Two years ago, FEMA allocated over $9.4 billion to repair and modernize Puerto Rico’s electrical grid — the largest allocation of funds in the history of the agency.

Soto, who has no kids, said her electrical bill was on average $80 per month before LUMA. Now it is $155.

In December 2022, the average price of residential energy on the island was a little over 25 cents per kilowatt hour. The U.S. average is just under 15 cents. In Chapel Hill, North Carolina, the price is about 10 cents per kWh.

Between 2014 and 2021, the year LUMA took over, the average energy cost for a household in Puerto Rico was about 15% lower than it is now. 

According to PowerOutage.Us, which tracks electric utilities across the country, Puerto Rico often has more customers without power than most states, including those with larger populations.

The power goes out often in the middle of the day when there is seemingly nothing wrong or when there’s a routine storm, the workers said.

On April 5, nearly 30 percent of the island was without power. LUMA’s website noted two “unplanned” outages of over 5,000 customers.

[OUTAGE MAP?]

Public frustration with LUMA has escalated to the point where Soto said she wants “nothing to do” with her former co-workers who went to work for LUMA.

“Traitors,” Moulier called them.

a brighter future

Despite transmission privatization, PREPA is still struggling financially.

In February, nearly 10,000 retirees were informed that they soon may lose their pension due to fund insolvency. A proposed electrical price increase would have residents pay $19 more a month — in hopes of PREPA restructuring debt.

The government is seeking to also offload its power generation.

In April 2022, a fire at one of Puerto Rico’s main power plants caused a massive blackout for millions on the island. On average, Puerto Rican power generation equipment is about 45 years old, twice the average on the U.S. mainland.

Genera PR, a subsidiary of a New York-based energy company, is set to take over the operation and maintenance of Puerto Rico’s power generation later this year. 

Like during the LUMA privatization, PREPA workers will  have a choice to either go with Genera or be transferred to other government agencies.

Ralphie Dominicci, 55, said he plans to retire instead of going into the private sector. After working for 34 years at a diesel power generator plant, he said there have been some guarantees about salary but it is unclear how workers’ pension plans would transfer — if at all.

“You move in the government, you move with your rights with your collective bargaining, too. You move to the same pension plan, too,” he said.

But the federal government admits that Puerto Rico’s heavy reliance on petroleum is a main contributor to some of the highest energy costs in the country.

Part of Genera PR’s 10-year contract includes decommissioning some of the island’s 12 power plants in a step toward saving money. Puerto Rico also has an ambitious goal of using 100% renewable energy by 2050. 

In December, Congress allocated $1 billion to establish a new Puerto Rico Energy Resilience Fund which is set to be used to fund new residential rooftop solar projects as well as energy resilience solutions like community microgrids and training.

And while every community does not have a Casa Pueblo, a visit in March by the U.S. Energy Secretary Jennifer Granholm to Adjuntas highlights the impact small communities can have on nationwide sustainability efforts.

“The energy insurrection is advancing community self-management, seeking to achieve the alternative homeland that we are talking about right now and she dreamed of,” Massol said, referring to his now deceased wife. “We are moving forward with the same dream, because we are all Puerto Rican people with the same desire to succeed.”
